item.title: The 1000 Genomes Project Pilot Phase Complete
item.description: The 1000 Genomes Project, a major international collaboration to build a detailed map of human genetic variation, has completed its pilot phase. The results are now published in the journal Nature and freely available through the EBI. The study provides valuable insights into the nature of human genetic variation and will underpin the next phase of human genetic research.

item.title: InterPro release 29.0
item.description: We are pleased to announce the release of InterPro 29.0, which contains 21123 entries and includes an update to PROSITE patterns and profiles (20.66), Gene3D (3.3.0), PIRSF (2.73), SUPERFAMILY (1.73) and SMART (6.1) and the integration of 731 new methods from the HAMAP, Gene3D, PIRSF, SUPERFAMILY and SMART databases; the release covers 79.4% of UniProt Knowledgebase release 2010_11. UniParc (uniparc_match.tar.gz) and UniMES (unimes_match.tar.gz) matches to InterPro methods have been updated and are available from the ftp site. Please note that the new release of InterProScan (v4.7) has been delayed for about 1 week. When the new version of InterProScan is ready, subscribers to InterProScan-announce will be informed and the InterProScan FTP site will be updated. If you have any questions about this, please contact us using our online support form. For full details of the release please see the Release Notes.

item.description: The Times' 'Eureka 100', published 7 October, lists EBI Director Janet Thornton among today's most important contributors to science. 'This award reflects the importance of the EBI, which is at the heart of biology and medicine today,' Janet commented. The EBI helps researchers to make the most of the daily data downpour... more

item.description: Interactions of the immunoglobulin superfamily (IgSF) proteins is new. Revised topics include Transmembrane transport of small molecules, Metabolism of proteins, Hemostasis, Immune system signaling, Insulin receptor signaling, GPCR signaling, Integration of energy metabolism, and Synaptic transmission. A recent paper describes the annotation of GPCR families in Reactome... more

item.title: 18th release of BioModels Database
item.description: In this release, 157 new models have been published. The public version of BioModels Database now contains 269 models in the curated and 361 in the non-curated branch. Together, these 630 models comprise 79224 species and 109091 reactions. Moreover, the database now features 20426 cross-references. Along with the data release, several new converters were also introduced, such as BioPAX Level 3 and Octave... more

item.title: Third mosquito genome sequenced
item.description: EBI scientists have contributed to annotation and analysis of the genetic blueprint of the Southern house mosquito, Culex quinquefasciatus, published today in the journal Science. An important vector of human diseases ranging from West Nile virus to filarial worms, Culex is the third mosquito to have its genome sequenced. Expansions of several gene families may contribute to Culex’s ability to thrive in diverse environments... more

item.title: New genomic variation database will support research into genetic diseases
item.description: Today sees the launch of the Database of Genomic Variants archive (DGVa) – a public catalogue of the large-scale insertions, deletions, duplications and rearrangements that are found in the genomes of individuals within a species. The new database is announced today in the journal Nature Genetics... more

item.title: High resolution insights to the regulation of transcript processing in eukaryotic cells
item.description: A paper in Nature Structural and Molecular Biology released online today finally ends speculation on whether a protein involved in splicing regulation functions as a repressor or facilitator of splicing. It does both! The study, authored by researchers from EMBL-EBI, Cambridge and Slovenia, used a new high-resolution technique to pinpoint the precise transcript binding positions of the protein... more

item.title: Making enough red blood cells
item.description: In a study published today in the Journal of Experimental Medicine, scientists at the European Molecular Biology Laboratory (EMBL) in Monterotondo, Italy, and EMBL’s European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI) in Hinxton, UK, have identified two small RNA molecules which ensure that enough red blood cells are produced efficiently, by fine-tuning a number of different genes involved in this process ...more

Highlights of this release are: - New assemblies and genebuilds for marmoset and C.elegans - New regulation views, including wiggle plots for each cell line - Many tables on web displays are now sortable and searchable, and individual columns can be hidden For more information visit: http://www.ensembl.org/info/website/news/ For the latest news on the Ensembl project, visit our blog at http://ensembl.blogspot.com

item.title: EMBL-EBI's ChEMBL database receives chemical structure data from GSK, St Judes and Novartis
item.description: GSK and St Jude Children's Research Hospital, USA, have deposited compound data into the EBI's drug discovery database ChEMBL to coincide with the publication of two papers in this week's issue of Nature. This addition provides information on over 14,000 compounds known to act against the parasite responsible for transmitting malaria. Novartis have also added data to the resource. Providing free access to this information and integrating it with other publicly-held data will support researchers worldwide in developing new malaria treatments... more

item.title: Draft Neandertal genome published today
item.description: An international research team including researchers at EMBL-EBI have published the draft genome sequence of the Neandertal, an extinct human relative estimated to have died out approximately 30,000 years ago. The genome, published today in Science, allows direct comparison with the human genome to identify the differences that might account for advantageous human characteristics, and even provides evidence that Neandertals and early humans interbred... more

item.title: Using gene expression profiles to predict prognosis for autoimmune disease
item.description: A paper in Nature Medicine released online today reports that personalised treatment and the development of improved therapies to treat autoimmune disease might be one step closer. The study, authored by researchers from EMBL-EBI, Cambridge, Oxford and Singapore-based research centres identified three genes that could be used as prognostic biomarkers to guide treatment of autoimmune disease... more

item.title: Rewiring of gene regulation across 300 million years of evolution
item.description: As published today in Science, researchers from Cambridge, Glasgow and Greece have discovered a remarkable amount of plasticity in how transcription factors, the proteins that bind to DNA to control the activation of genes, maintain their function over large evolutionary distances... more

item.title: Variations on the genetic theme
item.description: By integrating gene expression data from an unprecedented variety of human tissue samples, EMBL-EBI researchers and their collaborators have for the first time produced a global map of gene expression. The full analysis behind this unique view of the genetic activities determining our appearance, function and behaviour is published today in Nature Biotechnology ...more

item.title: Songbird genome to aid understanding of learning, memory and more
item.description: In research published today in Nature, scientists including researchers from EMBL-EBI break the news that they have sequenced the zebra finch genome. This is only the second ever bird genome to be sequenced -- the first being that of the chicken. The zebra finch offers a unique opportunity for us to understand the genetics behind the wiring and re-wiring of our brains when we learn and memorise... more

item.title: From alpaca to zebra finch - a decade of cataloguing life's diversity
item.description: Today's publication in Nature of the genetic blueprint for the zebra finch marks 10 years of success for the Ensembl project in helping researchers to navigate the genomes of a Noah's Ark of species. Ensembl, a genome annotation system co-developed and jointly run by EMBL-EBI and the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute, played a major part in finding the genes and other functionally important features in the zebra finch genome... more

item.title: How heritable genetic events influence gene expression in humans
item.description: A Science paper released today uncovers the role of variation in chromatin structure on gene regulation and the heritability of these differences. The study, authored by researchers from EMBL-EBI and several USA research institutes, used data from the 1000 Genomes Project to compare chromatin structure at regulatory sites in the genome not only between individuals but also within an individual. Humans typically contain two copies of every gene but these copies can be expressed differently... more

item.title: Ensembl Genomes v4 Released
item.description: Features of the new release include the addition of new databases for the bread mould Neurospora crassa to the Ensembl Fungi division, the slime mould Dictyostelium discoides (built with the assistance of dictyBase) to Ensembl Protists, and the body louse Pediculus humanus (containing data provided by VectorBase) to Ensembl Metazoa. The release also includes new variation databases for Drosophila melanogaster (using data from the Drosophila Population Genomics Project) and Plasmodium falciparum; the update of existing variation databases for Arabidopsis thaliana and Vitis vinifera in Ensembl Plants; and the addition of three new clades to Ensembl Bacteria. Ensembl Genomes is available at http://www.ensemblgenomes.org.

item.title: Nucleoporins are a new class of chromatin-binding proteins
item.description: For the first time in a higher eukaryote, researchers at EMBL-EBI and their collaborators have demonstrated that the binding of nuclear pore components to large parts of the Drosophila genome is an additional mechanism involved in regulating gene expression. As published today in PLoS Genetics, the researchers identified two nucleoporins, Mtor and Nup153, that bind a quarter of the Drosophila genome at active chromosomal regions and define a major class of new proteins regulating gene expression... more

item.title: InterPro release 25.0
item.description: New features include: This release contains 1312 new methods, which include new methods from HAMAP (280509), Pfam (24.0), PIRSF (2.71) and TIGRFAMs (9.0). Please Note: Pfam release 24.0 matches were calculated using HMMER3. The majority of the updated signatures were stable; however some had significant increases or decreases in the numbers of proteins they matched (+/- 30% change), which changed the taxonomy and/or biology based on protein matches. We are reviewing these entries, checking that the InterPro entry annotation is still valid and reflects the taxonomy and biology of the proteins matched by the Pfam signatures. Those Pfam signatures which have not yet been through this review process were therefore temporarily removed from InterPro and will be re-integrated into the InterPro database during 2010. If you have any questions about this, please contact us via support. For full details of the release please see the Release Notes.

item.description: Biocatalogue.org - a curated registry of web services for the life sciences - is launched today. Providers, expert curators and users monitor the catalogue and provide high quality information on each service, including ratings. item.title: Sweden is the first country to pledge long-term funding for ELIXIR
item.description: The Swedish funding agencies (the Swedish Energy Agency, Fas, Formas, the Swedish Research Council and VINNOVA) have suggested the government to allocate a total of 19 million SEK (1.7 million Euro) over three years to ELIXIR and the Swedish Bioinformatics Infrastructure for Life Sciences (BILS), which would make Sweden the first country to secure long-term funding for ELIXIR. The Swedish government has expressed its intention to substantially increase research funding in several strategic areas, including national infrastructures, and a final decision along these lines is expected during the autumn 2009. Bioinformatics is increasingly important in the interpretation of these data. We are therefore very enthusiastic about this new long-term funding for the BILS bioinformatics infrastructure in Sweden, which works within a European perspective and interacts closely with ELIXIR"... more

item.description: The Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute and the EMBL-European Bioinformatics Institute have been rated as the top two most influential research institutions in the UK, according to results published this week. In addition, nine of the top 25 most influential UK researchers work at the Wellcome Trust Genome Campus near Cambridge, home to the two powerhouse institutes...more

item.title: Strength of European rat genetics research highlighted in special focus issue of Nature Genetics
item.description: Researchers from EMBL-EBI are among those who co-author seven articles in Nature Genetics as part of the EU funded project "European Rat Tools for Functional Genomics (EURATools)". The articles demonstrate the remarkable advances made in rat genetics since the sequencing of the rat genome four years ago... more

item.title: An unexpected way to cause leukaemia
item.description: Researchers from the European Molecular Biology Laboratory in Italy, the EMBL-European Bioinformatics Institute, UK, and the Universities of Harvard, USA, and Lund, Sweden, have used genetic engineering to introduce a mutation found in human leukaemia patients into mice. In the current issue of Cancer Cell they report that the mutation causes leukaemia by triggering innate genetic programmes that allow white blood cells to proliferate uncontrollably... more

item.title: International partnership to produce "gold standard" gene copy reference of the human genome
item.description: A collaboration between The Centre for Applied Genomics at The Hospital for Sick Children and the European Molecular Biology Laboratory's European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI) will collect, organize and curate genome-wide information, enhancing the translation of genetic information into new diagnostic, prognostic and therapeutic tools for the improved health of children... more

item.title: InterPro release 16.2
item.description: InterPro release 16.2 is out, it contains 16175 entries covering 76.2% of UniProtKB with new methods from PIRSF, Gene3D and SUPERFAMILY. A new Type, Conserved Site, has been created for PROSITE patterns that do not represent PTMs, Active Sites or Binding Sites. UniProtKB (match_complete.xml), UniParc (uniparc_match.tar.gz) and UniMES (unimes_match.tar.gz) matches to InterPro methods have been updated and are available from the ftp site. For full details of the release please see the Release Notes.
